name: Salvation
subtitle: The Doctrine of Redemption and Eternal Life Through Christ
description: Christian salvation (Greek: soteria, meaning 'deliverance' or 'preservation') represents the central doctrine of Christian theology - the belief that humanity, alienated from God through sin, can be reconciled to the divine and granted eternal life through Jesus Christ. This doctrine addresses humanity's fundamental problem: since the Fall of Adam and Eve in Eden, all people have inherited a corrupted nature inclined toward sin and stand under the condemnation of divine justice. Sin creates an unbridgeable gulf between holy God and fallen humanity, resulting in spiritual death and eternal separation. Christian soteriology (the theology of salvation) teaches that God, motivated by love rather than obligation, initiated a rescue plan culminating in the incarnation, sacrificial death, and resurrection of His Son. Through Christ's atoning work on the cross, the penalty for sin is paid, divine wrath is satisfied, and reconciliation becomes possible. Salvation is received through faith - trusting in Christ's finished work rather than human merit - and results in justification (being declared righteous), sanctification (progressive transformation), and ultimately glorification (complete restoration in the resurrection). Different Christian traditions emphasize various aspects of this multifaceted doctrine.

sections.Origins: The doctrine of salvation has roots in the Hebrew Scriptures' themes of redemption, covenant, and divine rescue. The Exodus narrative - God liberating Israel from Egyptian slavery - provided the primary Old Testament paradigm for salvation: God acting to deliver His people from bondage. Prophetic literature developed themes of a coming Messiah who would inaugurate a new covenant and bring ultimate deliverance. The suffering servant passages of Isaiah (particularly chapter 53) described one who would bear the sins of many. Early Christians interpreted Jesus's death and resurrection as the fulfillment of these prophecies, developing sophisticated soteriological frameworks in the New Testament epistles. Paul's letters to the Romans and Galatians articulate justification by faith, while Hebrews presents Christ as the ultimate high priest and sacrifice.
sections.Mythology: Christian salvation is grounded in specific historical/mythological events understood as divine intervention. The Fall narrative (Genesis 3) establishes humanity's predicament: through Adam's disobedience, sin and death entered the world, and all subsequent humans inherit this corrupted condition. The incarnation follows - God becoming human in Jesus of Nazareth to accomplish what humanity could not. Christ's sinless life fulfilled the law's demands; His death satisfied divine justice as He bore sin's penalty; His resurrection demonstrated victory over death and validated His saving work. The Ascension placed Christ at the Father's right hand as advocate, and Pentecost sent the Holy Spirit to apply salvation's benefits to believers. This narrative arc - creation, fall, redemption, restoration - provides Christianity's overarching story.
sections.Role: Salvation functions as the organizing principle of Christian theology and practice. It defines the human condition (fallen, sinful, unable to save oneself), God's character (just yet merciful, wrathful against sin yet loving toward sinners), Christ's mission (to seek and save the lost), and the purpose of the Church (to proclaim salvation and make disciples). Practically, salvation shapes Christian ethics (gratitude for grace motivates obedience), worship (celebrating redemption), and hope (confidence in eternal life). Different traditions emphasize different aspects: Catholic theology stresses sacramental mediation, Protestant traditions emphasize faith alone, Orthodox Christianity focuses on theosis (divinization). Debates over predestination, perseverance, and the order of salvation have generated rich theological development.
sections.Legacy: The Christian doctrine of salvation has profoundly shaped Western civilization and global culture. The concept of individual moral agency and personal responsibility before God influenced legal and political philosophy. The idea of universal human sinfulness paradoxically supported both human equality (all are equally fallen) and the need for restraining social structures. Missionary movements spread the salvation message globally, for better and worse transforming cultures. Art, literature, and music have extensively explored salvation themes - from Dante's Divine Comedy to spirituals and gospel music. The salvation narrative's structure (problem-solution, fall-redemption) became a template for secular narratives of progress and liberation. Debates over salvation's nature and recipients continue to animate Christian theology and interfaith dialogue.

keyDoctrines.original_sin: All humans inherit a corrupted nature from Adam, inclined toward sin and unable to save themselves
keyDoctrines.atonement: Christ's death satisfies divine justice, pays sin's penalty, and enables reconciliation
keyDoctrines.justification: Being declared righteous before God through faith, not by works
keyDoctrines.sanctification: Progressive transformation into Christlikeness through the Holy Spirit
keyDoctrines.glorification: Future complete restoration in the resurrection of the body

soteriologicalModels.name: Penal Substitution
soteriologicalModels.description: Christ bears the punishment sinners deserve, satisfying divine justice

soteriologicalModels.name: Christus Victor
soteriologicalModels.description: Christ defeats the powers of sin, death, and Satan through the cross and resurrection

soteriologicalModels.name: Moral Influence
soteriologicalModels.description: Christ's example of sacrificial love transforms human hearts

soteriologicalModels.name: Recapitulation
soteriologicalModels.description: Christ relives and redeems human experience, undoing Adam's failure

soteriologicalModels.name: Ransom
soteriologicalModels.description: Christ pays a price to liberate humanity from bondage to sin and Satan
